questions.text: Test performed on gas cylinders to check the quality of manufacturing?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

All of the listed tests - the tensile test, flattening test, and bend test – are performed on gas cylinders to check the quality of manufacturing. Gas cylinders used in medical practice are designed to withstand high internal gas pressure and rough handling during transport. To ensure their durability and safety, these mechanical tests are conducted on a sample from each batch of cylinders before they are marketed for use.

  • Tensile test: Measures the cylinder material's resistance to breaking when stretched.
  • Flattening test: Evaluates the ductility and weld integrity (though these are seamless, it tests the material's ability to withstand deformation).
  • Bend test: Assesses the material's ductility and ability to resist fracture when bent.
  • Impact test: (Also mentioned in the reference, alongside the others) measures the material's toughness and resistance to fracture under sudden impact.
  • Testing Frequency: These tests are performed on one cylinder from a batch of every 100 finished cylinders.

Key Takeaway:

Medical gas cylinders undergo stringent mechanical testing, including tensile, flattening, impact, and bend tests, to ensure they can safely withstand high pressures and rough handling.

questions.text: Pressure gauges used on the cylinders are generally of the type
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The pressure gauges used on medical gas cylinders are generally of the Bourdon type. These gauges are specifically designed for the approximate measurement of high pressures found within gas cylinders. This type of gauge operates based on the principle of a bent, hollow metal tube that straightens with applied pressure, which then moves an indicator needle.

  • Pressure gauges are found on the cylinder side of the regulator on anesthesia machines.
  • These gauges are typically of the Bourdon type.
  • Mechanism of Action: A Bourdon gauge consists of a hollow metal tube, bent into a part of a circle, connected to the pressure line. When pressure is applied to the inside of the tube, it tends to straighten. This movement is transmitted through a clockwork mechanism to an indicator needle, which displays the pressure.
  • Application: Bourdon gauges are used for approximate measurement of high pressures.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Bodok (Option A): This term is not typically associated with a type of pressure gauge for medical gas cylinders.
  • Ballik (Option B): This term is not typically associated with a type of pressure gauge for medical gas cylinders.
  • Hasil (Option D): This term is not typically associated with a type of pressure gauge for medical gas cylinders.

Key Takeaway:

Bourdon gauges are the standard type of pressure gauge used on medical gas cylinders to measure high cylinder pressures.

questions.text: Figure shows the pin index safety system in cylinders. Match the index to the correct gas from the table.
questions.solution:
• The pin-index system is a safety feature, designed to prevent wrong connectionof a cylinder containing one substance to a delivery system of different substance
  • For example, attaching a nitrous oxide cylinder to the oxygen delivery system would produce 100% N2O, while you may believe you are attempting to give 100% O2. This will cause lethal damage to the patient. To prevent such accidents, PISS (pin-index safety system)was introduced
  • The system works by having a series of holes drilled into the valve on top of the cylinder in particular positions for each gas - these correspond to pins on the anesthesia machine, which prevent connection unless the pins fit into the respective holes.

Common Pin Index Positions:

  • Oxygen: 2, 5
  • Nitrous Oxide: 3, 5
  • Air: 1, 5
  • Carbon Dioxide: 1, 6
  • Nitrogen: 1, 4
  • Entonox (50% Oxygen / 50% Nitrous Oxide): 7

Key Takeaway:

  • The Pin Index Safety System uses unique pin configurations for each medical gas cylinder to ensure that only the correct gas cylinder can be connected to its intended delivery system.

questions.text: While moving a patient from the operation theatre to the ICU, it is found that in the oxygen E-cylinder, 1000 PSI is remaining and the flow rate is 5 L/min, the remaining time is estimated to be:
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

To estimate the remaining time in an oxygen E-cylinder, we can use the approximate formula derived from Boyle's Law, considering the typical initial pressure and volume of an E-cylinder. Given a remaining pressure of 1000 PSI and a flow rate of 5 L/min, the approximate formula for remaining time in hours is:

t=(Remaining PSI×0.3)/Flow rate

Substituting the given values: t=(1000 PSI×0.3)/5 L/mint=300/5t=60 minutes t=1 hour

Thus, the remaining time is estimated to be 1 hour.

  • E-Cylinder Characteristics: For oxygen, the usual initial pressure (Pi) in an E-cylinder is approximately 1900-2200 PSI, and its full volume (Vr) is approximately 660 liters.
  • Principle (Boyle's Law): The pressure-volume relationship for gases in a cylinder generally follows Boyle's Law, which states that for a fixed amount of gas at constant temperature, the product of pressure and volume remains constant (P1V1=P2V2).
  • Exact Formula : t=(Pr×Vr)/(Q×Pi) Where:
    • Pr = Remaining pressure (PSI)
    • Vr = Volume of the E-cylinder (liters), which is 660 L for oxygen.
    • Q = Flow rate (L/min)
    • Pi = Initial pressure (PSI), which is 1900 PSI.
    • The 60 in the denominator (if converting minutes to hours directly in the formula).
  • Approximate Formula): This simplified formula is often used for quick estimation and builds in a margin of safety. It uses rounded values for Vr (down to 600 L) and Pi (up to 2000 PSI), leading to the 0.3 constant: t=(Remaining PSI×0.3)/Flow rate (The 0.3 factor comes from approx. 600L / 2000 PSI = 0.3 L/PSI).
  • Application to problem:
    • Remaining PSI = 1000 PSI.
    • Flow rate = 5 L/min.
    • Estimated time = (1000 PSI * 0.3) / 5 L/min = 300 / 5 = 60 minutes = 1 hour.

Key Takeaway:

  • For quick estimation of remaining oxygen time in an E-cylinder, use the approximate formula: Time (hours) = (Remaining PSI x 0.3) / Flow rate (L/min).

Reference:

https://journals.lww.com/anesthesia-analgesia/fulltext/2004/04000/a_method_to_quickly_estimate_remaining_time_for_an.61.aspx

questions.text: Match the following cylinders with the appropriate colour coding
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • Entonox (A) is a mixture of 50% Nitrous Oxide and 50% Oxygen. Its color coding is typically a blue body and shoulders with blue and white quarters (v).
  • Helium (B) is typically coded with a brown (ii)
  • Cyclopropane (C) is typically coded with an orange (i)
  • Carbon dioxide (D) is typically coded with a grey (iv)
  • Air (E) is a mixture of gases. Its color coding is typically a black/grey body and shoulders with black and white quarters (iii).
  • Importance of Color Coding: Color coding of medical gas cylinders is a vital safety feature designed to allow for rapid visual identification of the gas contained within, thereby preventing potentially fatal misadministrations.
  • Common Medical Gas Colour Codes:
    • Oxygen: Black body with white shoulders (or sometimes plain white body, depending on regional standards).
    • Nitrous Oxide: Blue body.
    • Air: Black/grey body and shoulders with black and white quarters
    • Carbon Dioxide: Grey
    • Entonox: Blue body and shoulders with blue and white quarters (for a 50:50 N2O : O2 mixture).
    • Helium: Brown.
    • Cyclopropane: Orange
  • Layers of Safety: Color coding works in conjunction with other safety systems like the Pin Index Safety System (PISS) and Diameter Index Safety System (DISS) to ensure gas safety.

Key Takeaway:

  • Accurate knowledge of medical gas cylinder color codes (e.g., Entonox-blue/white, Helium-brown, Cyclopropane-orange, Carbon dioxide-grey, Air-black/white) is essential for safe anesthesia practice and patient care.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are false.
The assertion is true but the reason is false.
Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is correct for assertion.
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not correct for assertion

questions.text:
Identify the correct option regarding the following
Assertion: It is important to store Entonox cylinders below -6°C.
Reason: If the temperature rises above -6°C, there is liquefaction and separation of its two components.
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Both the assertion and the reason provided are false. The assertion states that Entonox cylinders should be stored below -6°C, which is incorrect. In fact, Entonox cylinders should be stored above their pseudocritical temperature of -6°C. The reason given states that if the temperature rises above -6°C, there is liquefaction and separation. This is also false; the separation (lamination) occurs if the temperature drops below -6°C, causing the gases to liquefy and separate.

  • Entonox Composition: Entonox is a 50:50 mixture of nitrous oxide (N2O) and oxygen (O2).
  • Pseudocritical Temperature: For Entonox, the pseudocritical temperature is approximately -6°C.
  • Storage Temperature (Critical Point):
    • Entonox cylinders should be stored above -6°C. The recommended storage temperature range is typically between 10°C to 38°C.
    • If the temperature drops below -6°C, the two components (nitrous oxide and oxygen) liquefy and separate. This phenomenon is known as lamination.
  • Consequence of Lamination: If lamination occurs and the cylinder is used, the patient would initially receive a higher concentration of oxygen, followed by a higher concentration of nitrous oxide, which can be dangerous.
  • Storage Position: Entonox cylinders should ideally be stored in a horizontal position. If lamination is suspected (e.g., cold cylinder), it should be warmed to room temperature and inverted several times to remix the gases.

Key Takeaway:

  • Entonox cylinders must be stored ABOVE their pseudocritical temperature of -6°C to prevent liquefaction and subsequent separation (lamination) of its nitrous oxide and oxygen components.

questions.text: The capacity of an oxygen E cylinder is approximately ______ Litres
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The capacity of an oxygen E-cylinder, which is the most commonly used cylinder in an anesthesia machine, is approximately 660 liters. Among the given options, 650 liters is the closest approximation to this value. At full capacity, its pressure is typically around 1900 psig.

  • E-Cylinder Use: The E-cylinder is the most frequently used cylinder size found on an anesthesia machine.
  • Capacity: Its approximate full capacity for oxygen is 660 liters.
  • Pressure: When full, an oxygen E-cylinder typically has a pressure of approximately 1900 psig (pounds per square inch gauge).
  • For oxygen (which is stored as a gas at high pressure), the volume remaining in the cylinder is directly proportional to the pressure shown on the gauge (following Boyle's Law), unlike gases stored as liquids (e.g., nitrous oxide).

Key Takeaway:

An oxygen E-cylinder, commonly found on anesthesia machines, has an approximate capacity of 660 liters when full at 1900 psig.

questions.text: If pressure in a full nitrous oxide "E" cylinder is 745 PSI at 20°C, the pressure in a half-full cylinder will be about _______:
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The pressure in a half-full "E" cylinder of nitrous oxide will still be approximately 745 psi. This is because nitrous oxide is stored primarily as a liquid within the cylinder at 20°C, and the gaseous phase above the liquid maintains a constant vapor pressure as long as liquid is present. The pressure will only begin to fall once almost all the liquid has evaporated and only the gaseous phase remains. Therefore, the volume remaining in the cylinder does not directly reflect the pressure until a significant portion of the gas is used.

Key Takeaway:

  • The pressure gauge on a nitrous oxide cylinder remains constant at approximately 745 psi (at 20°C) as long as any liquid N2O is present.
  • Weighing the cylinder is the only reliable method to determine the actual volume of nitrous oxide remaining.
